fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.
fields.evidence_quote: This study aimed to investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a questionnaire into another language through a non-inferiority design.

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a medical outcome questionnaire from English to Danish in a non-inferiority design.
fields.evidence_quote: This study aimed to investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a medical outcome questionnaire from English to Danish in a non-inferiority design.

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: ChatGPT-4, with human oversight and face validation, may produce translations of medical outcome questionnaires comparable to traditional human translations.
fields.evidence_quote: This study demonstrates that ChatGPT-4, with appropriate human oversight, may produce translations of medical outcome questionnaires that are comparable to traditional human translations after a face validation process.

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any meaningful or intentional involvement of patients or the public in any phase of the research or implementation?
fields.evidence_quote: For this study, the questionnaire was translated from English to Danish twice, once using ChatGPT-4 and once by human translators [16]. A comparison of the translations was made before and after the face validation process, which involved a series of participant interviews aimed at improving the questionnaires and providing evidence for their face validity.

fields.name: Evaluation of Impact (Y/N)
fields.description: Did the study evaluate or measure the effect of patient/public engagement?
fields.evidence_quote: The primary objective was to compare the two translated questionnaires after face validation by assessing the readability, comprehension, usage of appropriate language, and the participants’ overall opinions.

fields.name: Type of Evaluation
fields.description: What type of method or framework was used to evaluate the impact of engagement (e.g., metrics, qualitative feedback, evaluation framework)?
fields.value: Likert scale assessments of readability, comprehension, language appropriateness, and overall opinion, plus preference selection.
fields.evidence_quote: For this assessment, participants answered four questions using a Likert scale from 1 to 5. Secondary outcomes included which version of the translation the participants preferred and whether they could guess which version was translated by human translators and ChatGPT-4, respectively.

fields.name: Impact of Engagement
fields.description: Describe any outcomes or changes attributed to patient/public engagement (e.g., design changes, improved recruitment, insights).
fields.value: Improved quality of ChatGPT-4 translation, as evidenced by non-significant differences in participant ratings after face validation.
fields.evidence_quote: After face validation, there were no significant differences regarding readability, comprehension, appropriate use of language, and overall opinion of the questionnaire (Table 2).
